name: Dubowitz Syndrome
description: Dubowitz syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by growth retardation, microcephaly, distinctive facial features, eczema, and mild to moderate intellectual disability. The severity of symptoms can vary widely among affected individuals. There is an increased risk of certain cancers, particularly leukemia and lymphoma.
symptoms: Distinctive facial features (high forehead, sparse hair, blepharophimosis, ptosis, broad or unusual nasal bridge, small chin)
prognosis: Variable; depends on the severity of symptoms and the presence of complications such as malignancy. Early diagnosis and management can improve the quality of life.
lifeExpectancy: Potentially shortened due to increased risk of malignancy, but many individuals live into adulthood with appropriate medical care.
diagnosticMethods: Clinical evaluation based on characteristic features
Genetic testing (exome sequencing, candidate gene analysis) to identify causative mutations, although a specific gene has not been definitively identified in all cases.
Chromosome analysis (to rule out other chromosomal abnormalities)

treatmentOptions.name: Special education and therapies (speech, occupational, physical)
Cancer treatment (chemotherapy, radiation, stem cell transplant)

keyResearchCenters: Academic medical centers with genetics departments

patientOrganizations.name: Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center (GARD)

eli5Summary: Dubowitz syndrome is a rare condition where kids grow slowly, have small heads, unique faces, skin problems like eczema, and may have trouble learning. They might also get sick more easily. Doctors help them with therapies and medicines to live healthier lives.
clinicalSummary: Dubowitz syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by prenatal and postnatal growth retardation, microcephaly, distinctive craniofacial features (including blepharophimosis, ptosis, high forehead, and unusual nasal bridge), eczema, and intellectual disability. Affected individuals may exhibit behavioral problems such as hyperactivity and impulsivity. Skeletal anomalies, including clinodactyly and syndactyly, are common. A significant concern is the increased risk of hematological malignancies, particularly leukemia and lymphoma. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by exclusion of other similar syndromes and, ideally, genetic testing, although the causative gene(s) remain elusive in many cases. Management involves supportive care, including growth hormone therapy, eczema management, special education, and surveillance for malignancy.
historicalBackground: Dubowitz syndrome was first described by Stanley Dubowitz in 1965, who reported on three unrelated children with similar clinical features. The etiology remained unknown, and diagnosis was based on clinical findings. Over the years, numerous case reports have expanded the understanding of the syndrome's phenotypic variability and associated complications.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Advancements in Exome Sequencing for Dubowitz Syndrome
recentBreakthroughs.description: While a definitive causative gene remains elusive for all cases, advancements in exome sequencing have aided in identifying potential candidate genes and excluding other genetic disorders with overlapping features. This has improved diagnostic accuracy and genetic counseling.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Improved Cancer Surveillance Protocols for Dubowitz Syndrome
recentBreakthroughs.description: Due to the increased risk of malignancy, updated surveillance protocols have been developed to facilitate early detection and intervention, improving outcomes for affected individuals.
